review_title: University Values Not Demonstrated when Managing On-site Employees
pros: Hollins University attracts employees based on it's perceived community and values. As a nonprofit private university supporting an all-female undergraduate population, employees feel like they contribute to an intimate community and can see the positive effects of their labor. Retirement matching contributions and benefits packages are competitive, particularly for a nonprofit institution.
cons: Many offices are located in out-of-date historic buildings without effective climate control systems. Mold is an ongoing (and reported) problem in several building structures that support administrative activities. Ongoing construction on campus can lead to a loud work environment, with electrical, plumbing, and IT systems offline for periods of time. Flooding and storm-related power outages affect mobility and productivity on the campus. The Human Resources department and higher administrative team are slow in responding or providing solutions to employee-raised issues of infrastructure, outdated work practices, interpersonal professional conflicts, and wage/salary reviews.

pros:
Good working environment

Good compensation

Not stressful
cons: Do not have much training

pros: Pretty, attractive campus. We have had an annual cost of living increase for the past several years. Good location, easy to commute to. Some faculty and staff are absolutely fantastic and wonderful to work with. A great quality educational institution, so proud to be associated with it.
cons: Does not invest in any sort of professional development for employees and many departments understaffed and overworked. Low morale is ignored. Severe lack of diversity. Upper management favors people who are attractive and who are Yes Men with doctoral degrees. Senior management not reviewed by the people who report to them so leadership issues are never addressed. No merit raises. Some of the people are immature and less than inspiring to work with.

pros: The people who care at this institution really care! The support staff was amazing! Kindhearted and sweet and thoughtful in the face of rich spoiled little girls who delighted in disrespecting them.
cons: If someone doesn't care, you can feel it. It seems like they hate you for existing. There is an embarassingly catty environment (not a good look for a women's institution.) People's concerns aren't taken seriously at all. They have students living in former slave quarters. They refuse to tenure a black professor. At this women's institution female professors get paid less than male professors and will tell their students so. There is no professionalism or mode of decorum. It was dangerous to my mental and physical health to remain at that institution. Every day felt like being hazed.

pros: Office culture is nice, and even. The employees work well. Circulation training is interesting and fun. They're more than willing to fit themselves into your schedule.
cons: When I was training for circulation, the program to learn Library of Congress Catologing system was long and arduous. It barely kept my interest and sometimes the other supervisors don't even bother talking to you about their problems with you when its all over something that can be considered personal, rather than professional.

review_title: Loved the experience of my job and and trust from management!
pros: I had the awesome opportunity to have a management position right out of college. My supervisor encouraged me to get necessary training in order to do my job best! (FREE MASTERS CLASSES) I think fondly of my time at Hollins and appreciate the professional and life skills they taught me.
cons: No Cons come to mind! LOVED working here!
